net.roydesign.ui
Class ApplicationDialog

java.lang.Object
  java.awt.Component
      java.awt.Container
          java.awt.Window
              java.awt.Dialog
                  java.awt.FileDialog
                      net.roydesign.ui.ApplicationDialog
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, javax.accessibility.Accessible
public class ApplicationDialog
extends java.awt.FileDialog

An application dialog is a modal file dialog to specifically select an application on disk. The dialog installs its own filename filter to only enable file system items that qualify as applications. Note however that this filtering mechanism isn't implemented on all platforms, specifically because Sun themselves didn't bother to implement it in their own Java VM for Windows. In this case, all files will be selectable by the user. The dialog also takes care of the system properties required on Mac OS X to make file dialogs not show application bundles as folders but as files, which means you don't have to worry about any of it.

Version:
MRJ Adapter 1.2
See Also:
Serialized Form

Method Detail

getApplicationFile

public ApplicationFile getApplicationFile()
Get the application file selected by the user. If the user cancels the operation, this method returns null. This method is a convenience which replaces the separate calls getFile() and getDirectory().

Returns:
the selected application file, or null

setMode

public void setMode(int mode)
Set the mode of the dialog. This method is overriden because it doesn't make sense in the context of an application dialog to allow selection of the mode. It will throw an error if you try to call it.

Overrides:
setMode in class java.awt.FileDialog
Parameters:
mode - the mode

show

public void show()
Make the dialog visible. Since the dialog is modal, this method will not return until either the user dismisses the dialog or you make it invisible yourself via setVisible(false) or dispose.

Overrides:
show in class java.awt.Dialog
